Simeon is requesting this loan to hire help for cleaning and pruning his three-acre cacao farm, as well as harvesting kuhun trees, which are producing too much shade. The task at hand will require and create over 200 hours of labor in the community. Cleaning means cutting underbrush to clear access to trees for pruning and harvest, or to prepare soil for planting. It is a routine activity for farmers working in the lush tropical lowlands, and needs to be repeated three to four times a year. Pruning means cutting excess branches to increase yields in the coming season and keep trees from intertwining with one another and growing too tall and unwieldy. The harvested kuhun trees will be useful in the household because of the delicious kahun cabbage – heart of the kahun palm, that can be used as a meat substitute.

loans.use: To clean and prune three acres of cacao farm.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.en:
Santiago is a farmer from Guatemala, who has been living in Belize since 1985. He lives with his wife Juana and their seven children in the village of Red Bank. The kids have been helping by transplanting, cutting and weeding the underbrush. 

“Belize is very pretty, we’re like in heaven here. There’s land to work,” says Santiago, pointing out that in his native Guatemala land is hard to come by. Besides cacao, the family grows beans, corn, coffee, cardamom, avocado and anatto. Annatto is a high bush that is used for making achiote, also known as recado – a reddish paste that is often used for spicing up tamales.  

Santiago started planting cacao just five years ago, after seeing a fellow villager with cacao seedlings and giving a try to the crop himself. “Cacao is very pretty,” says Santiago, adding that it’s of great use in the home too, as the hot chocolate drink makes for a tasty alternative to coffee. The Mayan chocolate drink is made by grinding dried, unfermented cacao beans and grinding them – usually by hand – into a paste that is then dissolved in water. 

The family is requesting this loan to transplant 400 seedlings from the on-site nursery as well as cleaning and pruning around 600 cacao trees. Transplanting is the process of planting into the ground seedlings that have been raised in bags for at least six months. The work will require hiring four people for two days of work, while Santiago plans to do the clearing work himself over a longer period of time. 

Santiago is currently saving up money to get his land surveyed so the family could get an official title to the land they are working. Private ownership already exists in Red Bank, however to claim it farmers need to hire surveyors. An alternative to privately owned land is a communal land system that is still commonplace in many Mayan villages throughout Belize.

loans.use: To clean and prune cacao fields and transplant new seedlings.

loans.name: Florentino

texts.en:
Florentino, his wife Eustachia and their seven boys live in the village of Red Bank, Stann Creek district of Belize. Their oldest – 21 year old – has graduated college and is employed in town, while their youngest is now just four years old. Five of the boys are currently enrolled in school, meaning they’re mostly unable to help out on the farm, and Eustachia is more than busy taking care of the very masculine household. 

Florentino has been farming around 3,000 cacao trees dispersed over five acres of lush tropical lowlands for seven years now. Taught to plant cacao by his father, he maintained his interest throughout school and started soon after graduating. The land in this area is very good, says Florentino, who also grows his fresh veggies, peanuts, corn and beans all organic. Besides farming, the family also runs a bed and breakfast. Red Bank is renowned for spotting Scarlet Macaws, who forage there in the winter months to feed off the annatto fruit abundant in this area. 

The family is requesting this loan in order to hire help with harvesting, cleaning, and pruning mature trees. Harvesting will require help of four people once a week during the productive season, while cleaning and pruning will require around 9 people for 14 days.  

Florentino is a visionary community leader, who is invested in the wellbeing of his village. He wants to grow his farm and business, so that “everybody can benefit in my village,” he says. With little government intervention, Red Bank farms have no road access, an issue Florentino is trying to address on the community-level. Also, concerned with opportunities for the younger generation, who lacks alternatives for meaningful pastime, Florentino has funded and wants to continue efforts to expand afterschool activities. The family wants to provide their boys with a good education “so one day they can help one another,” Florentino told Maya Mountain Cacao.

loans.use: Hire help with harvest, cleaning and pruning cacao fields.

loans.name: Placido

texts.en:
Placido and Florentina live in the Mayan village of Pueblo Viejo, which lies next to an under way highway that will connect western Belize with eastern Guatemala. They raised seven children, aged between 17 and 32, all of who have jobs and live outside of the village communities. Two of the youngest are currently studying in the University of Belize, and all others have already completed schooling. 
 
“I did hard work to send every single one to school,” says Placido. The couple works the farm together - Florentina helps with tasks like setting up nurseries, filling the bags with seeds and harvesting, as do the kids when they’re around. Cleaning, however, is something Placido either has to do himself or hire outside help.  Cacao is a good crop, he assures, because it’s permanent: “rain or shine, it’s there,” he says. A cacao farmer of five years and counting, Placido got into the business by recommendation: “I always listen to good advice,” he told Maya Mountain Cacao. He started by buying bags and cacao fruit for seeds that he himself planted into bags instead of starting from pre-raised seedlings. “Most people told me I can’t do it, because that’s not how it’s done,” he said, confessing that he himself was relieved and very happy once his cacao started bearing fruit.  

For Placido, the best part of farming is his routinely check on the farm, when he visits the nursery and trees to check on progress. The hardest is cleaning the bush, he says, adding that it’s especially tricky when you have freshly planted cacao, which you can accidentally chop together with the surrounding underbrush. Besides farming, Placido has a side cattle business and runs a little grocery store in Pueblo Viejo. In the future, if health allows, he hopes to expand what he already started – the cacao farm, cattle, improve his shop and continue working on his house to better accommodate the regularly visiting kids. The family hopes they’ve set a good example for their children, who can each accomplish more than their parents because of the added benefit of education. “I can do little. They’re going to school and getting valuable experience, so they can do more,” he says. 

Florentina and Placido are requesting this loan to hire help to clean around 500 newly planted trees over two acres of tropical lowlands. Cleaning means clearing the underbrush to open access to cacao trees, which grow literally in the middle of the jungle. Farmers typically clean three to four times a year to keep their trees accessible. The job at hand will require hiring four people to clear the underbrush for 2 weeks.

loans.use: Clean 2 acres of recently transplanted cacao trees.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is 51 years old, married and has five children. She has a small vegetable stand where she sells a variety of fruits and vegetables. She has several years of experience and she started the business to support her husband.
Tabitha now wants to expand her business. The amount of products she sells is not enough to cover high demand. She would like to purchase more fruit and vegetables in order to increase turnover, as well as to help improve living conditions for her family. For this purpose, she has applied for a 20,000 KES loan.

loans.use: to purchase more fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Fileon

texts.en:
Fileon and Bernarda are raising five children and farm around 4.5 acres of cacao in the village of Pueblo Viejo. The kids are aged five to 13, and three are currently in school. Besides farming, Bernarda and Fileon make crafts to sell in town – hand-carved calabash ornaments and lamp shades among other decorative items.

Fileon got the idea to plant cacao eight years ago after meeting a chocolate maker while selling his crafts in town and subsequently requesting bags to raise cacao seeds from the local co-op. He then proceeded to clear some bush to make room for the cacao under the canopy of native trees and has been caring for it ever since. Besides the access to market for one of very few viable cash crops in Belize, the family likes cacao for use at the home. “I like it, because I roast some and then drink it instead of coffee,” says Fileon, adding that store-bought coffee is probably not good for you, while cacao keeps him healthy and working hard. For Fileon, the best part of cacao farming is seeing the trees clean and nicely pruned. The most challenging is that cacao grows naturally in an environment shared with animals, who enjoy chewing on the roots – like peccaries, and the fruit – like squirrels and birds, says Fileon. 

The family is happy to be able to send their kids to school, which in Belize comes with tuition for each child in any level of public education. Fileon says he hopes the kids end up going to university, as it was something he would have wanted, but didn’t get the opportunity to do himself. “Now they have options, they can work the farm or get other jobs too,” Fileon told Maya Mountain Cacao. In the future, Fileon wants to start working on a house of a more appropriate size for his large family and to keep busy with the crafts and farm. 

The family is requesting this loan to clean and prune around 1,500 productive cacao trees and set up a nursery for 500 new plants. Cleaning is done by using a machete to clean underbrush that continually grows around cacao trees, in order to make them accessible for pruning and harvest. Pruning is the process of cutting excess branches from trees to keep them from intertwining with one another and producing at their highest capacity. Planting requires bagging seeds that are kept in a nursery until the seedlings have around 4 leaves and are ready for transplantation into the ground. The job at hand will require and create the equivalent of 22 days of labor in the community.

loans.use: Clean and prune 1,500 cacao trees, set up new nursery.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 27-year-old Fatmata from Calabatown in the eastern area in Freetown. She is a single mother with two children, ages 3 and 8. She describes herself as a hardworking woman. She decided to start a business to create income for herself since she did not go to school.

Fatmata runs a provisions store; she sells milk, sugar, Ovaltine and pure water. She has been running this business for five years. She works at the business every day, from morning to night. Her business is the only source of income she has. She describes her major problem as insufficient capital to run her business.  

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to buy more provision items like milk, sugar, Ovaltine and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, she plans to have a permanent residence on her own. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more provision items like milk, sugar, Ovaltine and pure water.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a married man. He lives with his wife and three children in a town called Kwale. He says that before he started his business, he traveled abroad in search of better opportunities. Because of that, he and his wife were able to accumulate a significant amount of capital and decided to return to Kenya. They built their house and decided to open a store for selling goats with their savings. Thanks to effort and hard work his business has expanded. He now has a steady clientele because of the good and friendly service he provides his customers.

He is requesting a loan to purchase more goats. The loan amount of 35,000 Kenyan shillings will also be used to transport the goats bought.

loans.use: to purchase more goats.

loans.name: Umu

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 27-year-old Umu from Calaba town. She is married with one child, aged 7 years. Her child is attending school. 

Umu runs a general store; she sells pure water, soft drinks, milk, cigarettes and toothpaste. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business every day, from morning to night. She supplements her business with tailoring. She says that the main challenge to her business is price inflation.

Umu has requested a loan in order to buy more pure water, soft drink, milk, and cigarette and toothpaste. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her standard of living and educate her child. In the future, she plans to own a supermarket. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more pure water, soft drinks, milk, cigarettes and toothpaste.

loans.name: Maria Petronila

texts.es: María, tiene 36 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene una hija,  y vive con su padre e hija en una aldea del municipio de Puerto Cortes. María siempre ha sido comerciante, hace 11 años que estableció su propio negocio de pulpería donde vende granos básicos, productos de limpieza, refrescos, churros, pastillas, condimentos, etc. además vende ropa, uniformes y otros productos que piden sus clientes. Ha solicitado dos préstamos a ODEF con el actual que es por 10,000 Lempiras, con este préstamo va surtir el negocio de ropa, uniformes escolares y más productos alimenticios para la pulpería. Ella invirtió este préstamo con el objetivo de aumentar el inventario y ventas en su negocio aprovechando la temporada escolar. Su meta es seguir creciendo como comerciante y brindarle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
María is 36 years old, a single mother, and has a daughter. She lives with her father and her daughter in a village in the municipality of Puerto Cortes. Maria has always had a business, and 11 years ago, set up her own small general store where she sells basic staples, cleaning products, soft drinks, snacks, pills, condiments, etc. In addition, she sells clothing, uniforms, and other products that her customers ask for.

She has applied for two loans from ODEF, including the current one, which is for 10,000 lempiras. With this loan she is going to stock her store with clothing, school uniforms, as well as more food products for the general store. 

She invested this loan with the aim of increasing inventory and sales in her business, taking advantage of the back-to-school season. Her goal is to continue growing as a businessperson, and to offer a better quality of life to her family.

loans.use: To buy food products for stocking her small general store and to buy uniforms and clothing to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Lyn

texts.en:
Ma. Lyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Ma. Lyn requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy more bread, biscuits and soft-drinks.

She has been in this business for 15 years.

In the future, Ma. Lyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more bread, biscuits and soft-drinks.

loans.name: Milly Elezabeth

texts.en:
As a married parent of eight children, Milly Elezabeth works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling dried coconut meat business in the Philippines and earns additional income from running a bakery and from pig fattening. Milly Elezabeth is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional dried coconut meat to sell for her buying and selling dried coconut meat business.

Milly Elezabeth has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional dried coconut meat to sell

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa runs her rolling store wherein she offers a variety of vegetables, fruits, native cakes, meat such as pork and chicken and different kinds of ingredients. She has been doing this kind of business for four years. Teresa is 42 years old, married and has four children. All her four children are still studying, that's the reason why she doubles her effort to earn for greater profit.

Teresa used to transport her goods using her motorcycle. She aims to put up her own stall so that she could economize her expenses on transporting her goods. In order to obtain her goal, she is requesting for additional capital of PHP15,000 which will be use to buy vegetables, meat, native cakes, fish and fruits so she could increase her sales and profit. She knows that her success relies on how she handles her food production business and also economizing her family household expenses, most especially their monthly electric bill. In this way, she could save a greater amount for her children's future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, meat, native cakes, fish and fruits for her food production sales

loans.name: Demetrio

texts.en:
Demetrio is widowed with 5 children. Demetrio is 66 years old and lives in San Miguel, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte.
Demetrio owned a general store to earn a living and had this business for 12 years. Each month, he earns 5000 doing this type of work. He has requested a loan of 20000 to purchase more stocks for her general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, vinegar and etc.
Demetrio has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. In the future, Demetrio hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks for his general store such as shampoo, toothpaste, soap, salt, vinegar and etc.

location.town: Liloy-San Miguel, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
This is Mary Jane. She previously accessed an 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories and for the maintenance of their jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan for her to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their jeepney unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mary Jane hopes to have more businesses and dreams to give her children a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

-Curiously, Jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for every day travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of the jeepney.

loans.name: Felecidad

texts.en:
Felecidad is a 56-year-old married woman from Bien Unido, Bohol, Philippines. She operates a sari-sari or variety store business selling various goods and commodities to the people in her town. Felecidad wants to improve her stocks so that she will be able to attract and cater to more customers and buyers in her store. Felecidad is asking for a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, chips, biscuits, soap and toiletries. 

In the future, Felecidad hopes to make her business grow and profitable.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, noodles, rice, chips, biscuits, soap and toiletries

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita is a 53 year old married woman and a mother of adult children from Bien Unido, Bohol. She and  her husband are in fishing business. Her husband works as a fisherman.

Warlita sells the fish that her husband catches to the people in her community. She also sells seaweed on the mainland. Warlita works hard to help her husband to meet the family's needs. Warlita has requested a loan to buy more seaweed and fish to sell. She dreams of expanding their business and increasing their income. Moreover, she wants to save money for future use and to reinvest in their business.

loans.use: to buy more seaweed and fish to sell

loans.name: Ma. Riza

texts.en:
Ma. Riza is a 28-year-old married woman from San Miguel, Bohol. She has one 4-year-old son. She has been engaged in a food vending business for three years now. She earns 3,000 PHP per month. This is the source of her income. Her husband works in a private establishment.

Ma. Riza is requesting a loan to buy meat, chicken, vegetables and seasonings. This are the ingredients of her food vending business; she sells in her local community. By the use of this loan, she will be able to buy these ingredients and sell prepared food.

In the future, Ma. Riza hopes to expand her business and to gain more profit.

loans.use: to buy  meat, chicken, vegetables and seasonings

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy oil, detergent, slippers, cigarettes, salt and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 40 years old and she has a store in front of her house to sell local products, such as traditional clothes, bags, purses and many more things. She will use the loan to buy cotton, cotton gin, palm leave, ink, knife and other things.
She opened this store in 2008 with her own working capital of $ 40.00. She also has a farm to cultivate corns, papayas and bananas, which she can sell to earn some extra income.

loans.use: To buy the items needed for weaving such as cotton and cotton gin

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.ru:
Олимжон мужчина в возрасте 44 лет, он женат и имеет  4 детей.   Он работает пастухом  на ферме.    Имея большой опыт скотоводства, он  дома также содержит скот овец, коз и корову.   Его жена и старший сын помогают ему в разведении скота.    Жена также  продает молоко и молочные продукты.  Этот бизнес у них очень хорошо развевается. Олимжон старается делать все чтобы его семья не в чем не нуждалась. 
 Сейчас он хочет купить скот и до весны откормив продать по выгодной цене так как весной скот подорожает. 
На полученный кредит Олимжон планирует купить несколько голов скота и расширить свой бизнес.   Он заранее благодарит организацию Кива за финансовую поддержку и помощь.
texts.en:
Olimjon is a 44-year-old man. He is married and has 4 children. Olimjon works as a shepherd at a farm. Having a lot of experience with livestock, he also keeps sheep, goats and a cow at home. His wife and eldest son help him take care of the animals. Olimjon's wife also sells milk and dairy products. This business is developing very well. Olimjon does everything he can to make sure that his family is not wanting for anything.

Presently, Olimjon would like to purchase livestock and, after fattening it, sell it in spring, when the price of livestock goes up. He plans to use this loan to buy several animals, thereby expanding his business. Olimjon thanks Kiva in advance for the financial support and help.

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: Sadafmo

texts.ru:
Садафмо жительница района Рудаки. Ей 36 лет. Она разведена. У нее один ребенок. Садафмо имеет среднее образование. Она три года проработала продавщицей в продуктовом магазине. Сейчас у нее свой небольшой продуктовый магазин. Она работает продавщицей в собственном магазине. Торговлей Садафмо занимается более пяти лет.
Садафмо берет кредит для покупки продуктов питания: муки, макарон, риса, газированных напитков, масла, молочных продуктов, сахара, чая, вафель и печенья.
texts.en:
Sadafmo lives in the Rudaki region of Tajikistan. She is 36 years old, divorced, and has a child. Sadafmo has secondary education. For three years, she worked as a clerk in a grocery store. Now, she has her own small food shop and works there. In total, Sadafmo has been in retail for over five years.

Sadafmo is taking this loan to buy food products: flour, pasta, rice, carbonated beverages, oil, dairy products, sugar, tea, waffles and cookies.

loans.use: to buy food products and increase her sales volume

loans.name: Raikan

texts.ru: Райкан оплатила остаток первого кредита в срок. Она очень довольна результатами проекта.Она обратилась в банк "Бай Тушум и партнеры" за кредитом 70,000 KGS на приобретение скота в связи с низкими ценами на скот.
texts.en: Raikan has repaid the balance of her first loan on time. She is very pleased with the results of her project. She has once again turned to the Bai Tushum & Partners bank for a loan of 70,000 KGS to purchase livestock, as livestock prices are currently low.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Toktokhan

texts.ru: Токтохан очень благодарна всем кто подержал её. Токтохан очень довольна результатами первого проекта. Токтохан повторно обратилась к фонду КИВА за поддержкой, на это раз она планирует увеличить доходы путем приобретения одной лошади. После откорма лошади, она планирует продать её по более высокой цене. Для осуществления данного проекта её необходимо 50,000 KGS.В этом году она планирует женить младшего сына.
texts.en:
Toktokhan is very grateful to all who supported her. She is very pleased with the results of her first project.

Toktokhan is once again turning to Kiva for assistance, but this time she plans to increase her profits by purchasing a horse. After fattening the animal, she will sell it at a higher price. In order to implement this plan, she needs 50,000 KGS.

This year, Toktokhan is planning to hold a wedding for her youngest son.

loans.use: to purchase a horse

loans.name: Nurgul

texts.ru:
Очень рада тому что её кредит прошел по линии КИВА. Она восхищается работай и идеями фонда. От всей души благодарит всех людей которые поддерживает людей во всем мире.Первый проект помог ей развить свой хозяйство и увеличить свои доходы
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Нургул обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS)  на закуп дополнительных голов скота. Доходы от кредита Нургул планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение хозяйства.
texts.en:
Nurgul is very happy that she received a loan from Kiva. She admires the work and ideas of this organization. From the bottom of her heart, she thanks all lenders who support people all over the world.

Nurgul's first project helped her develop her business and increase her profits. In order to continue expanding her farm, she has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 50,000 som (KGS) to purchase additional livestock. Nurgul plans to invest her profits from this loan into further growth of her business.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Shaarkan

texts.ru: Шааркан 42 год, замужем, имеет 3 детей. В 2002 году, в поисках источника дохода для своей семьи, Шааркан начала свой бизнес в животноводстве со стартовой суммы в 5,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорству и настойчивости, на сегодняшний день она имеет очень развитое хозяйство. Ежемесячная прибыль составляет около 8,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молока. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Шааркан обратилась в компанию «Бай-Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 60,000 сом (KGS) на покупку коров, для увеличения доходов от продажи молока. В будущем, Шааркан хочет увеличить хозяйство и расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Shaarkan is 42 years old, married, and has 3 children. In 2002, while looking for a source of income for her family, Shaarkan launched her own livestock business with an initial sum of 5,000 som (KGS). Thanks to her persistence and tenacity, today she runs a very well developed dairy farm. Her monthly profits total roughly 8,000 som (KGS) from sales of milk.

In order to continue growing her business, Shaarkan has turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 60,000 som (KGS) to purchase cows and thereby increase her income from milk sales. In the future, Shaarkan would like to increase the size of her herd and further expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase dairy cows

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy blouses, shirts, jeans, and Islamic fashions to resell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is from Tirebe mombasa, a city of Kenya. She is the owner of a food kiosk. Asha has been doing this work for more than two years and she has become very well known among the customers who go there. She is a person with a lot of enthusiasm who likes to get ahead. That is why she works so hard. She works from very early in the morning to prepare the dishes she sells, and she returns home late at night.

Asha is requesting this loan, amounting to KES 35,000 to be able to buy beverages and supplies for her kiosk. This is what she needs most and uses everyday. She's grateful for this opportunity because with it, she's making progress.

loans.use: to buy beverages and supplies to make her meals to sell.

loans.name: Umu

texts.en:
Umu is 50 years old and married. She has 2 children, aged 19 and 25. She runs a general merchandise store in Calaba town, in the eastern area in Freetown. One of her children is married and the other one is in university.

Umu has been in this business for 5 years and sells pure water, milk, Ovaltine and assorted drinks. She also earns additional income with a commercial vehicle. 

She is requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy more food commodities like pure water, milk, Ovaltine and assorted drinks. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to increase her business and build a build a house. In the future, she would like to further expand her business. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy more food commodities like pure water, milk, Ovaltine and assorted drinks.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Meet 55-year-old Alex from Calaba town, eastern area in Freetown. He is married and has 2 children, ages 18 and 21. His children are currently attending school. In 2008, Alex established his bar and restaurant business. He began his business because there is a high demand for bars and restaurants within the area. He works at the business from 11:00am until 1:00am, 6 days per week. He says that the main challenge to his business is electric power supply.

Alex requires a loan in order to buy cartoned stout, beer, pure water and cooking oil. He hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow him to pay one of his children's university fees. In the future, Alex plans to open another bar in a different location. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more cartons of stout, beer, pure water and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bee hives and to pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Meet 28-year-old Abass from Waterloo Branch, in Sierra Leone. He is married and has 1 child, aged 4 years. His child is currently attending school. He has been in business for 9 years, selling local produce like rice, beans etc. He started this business because he wants his family life to improve. He works at the business from 7am until 6pm, 7 days per week. He says that the main challenges to his business are transportation and sales competition from other stores.

Abass requires a loan in order to buy more local food stuff like rice and beans. He hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow him to expand his business. In the future, Abass plans to expand his business and create more employment for other people. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more local food stuff like rice and beans.

loans.name: Sese

texts.en:
Sese sells provisions in Apowa, near Takoradi. Sese has received no formal education. She is married and has 3 children. Her husband is a driver. 

Sese has been selling provisions for the past 8 years. She is responsible for assisting her husband with their family’s expenses. Her loan will be used to buy a greater quantity and variety of provisions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her provision selling business.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and variety of provisions to sell.

loans.name: Javan

texts.en:
Javan is a resident of Likoni, Kenya. He is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. Javan owns a motor cycle which he uses to transport people and goods within the area. He is also formally employed.

Javan joined Milango after being informed about the services by his friends. He is applying for a loan of 21,050 Kenya shillings to purchase motor cycle spare parts and to pay for repairs to the motorcycle. He faces the challenge of high fuel prices but is determined to carry on with the business. He will use the extra income to pay for his children's school fees and is also focused on owning a three wheeler vehicle in the future.

loans.use: to purchase motor cycle spares and to repair the motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his inventory of spare tire for resale.

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is a resident of Likoni, Kenya. She is a married mother of two school aged children. She runs a guest house that has been operating for the last five years. She employs two other people in the business. She is also formally employed.

Tabitha was invited to Milango by her friends and joined in order to access credit. She is applying for a loan of 41,900 Kenya shillings to renovate the guest houses. The challenge she faces in the business is political instability, but she is hopeful that the business will pick up and enable her to earn more income to educate her children. Her ambition is to own more guest houses in the future.

loans.use: to renovate the guest houses.

loans.name: Rugiatu

texts.en:
Meet 45-year-old Rugiatu from Torpoi town Bo, Southern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with 4 children between the ages of 8 and 26 years. Two of her children are currently attending school. In 1997, Rugiatu established her retail business. She began her business because she was trained in business; she thinks that business is the best for her. She works at the business every day, going door-to-door to introduce her new products to her customers. She says that her main challenges are inadequate capital to expand her business and an unsuitable business location from which to operate.

Rugiatu requires a loan in order to buy more suitcases, bags, food containers and pots. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and open a savings account. In the future, Rugiatu plans to open a big general merchandise store. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more suitcases, bags, food containers and pots.

loans.name: Angel Ulises

texts.es:
Ángel es un joven de 25 años, con mucho esfuerzo terminó la secundaria, es soltero y gracias al espíritu emprendedor que heredó,  se ha forjado camino para salir adelante por su familia; su hijo y su pareja con quienes vive en la Parroquia de Río Verde de Santo Domingo, la capital de la Provincia de Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas, una provincia de Ecuador que en los últimos años ha tenido un alto crecimiento sostenido. Su capital  es una ciudad en donde lo más atractivo y llamativo son sus deliciosas frutas, y la gastronomía que ofrecen en el lugar. Su comercio considerable  ya que se ha convertido en un puerto terrestre de intercambio comercial entre las regiones Sierra y Costa del país. Cuenta con varios atractivos turísticos que acompañados de su clima cálido son muy concurridos por turistas nacionales y extranjeros. Es por esto que la mayoría de sus habitantes han emprendido con alguna actividad comercial o de servicios para habitantes y turistas.
Ángel aprendió de su padre la labor de realizar acabados de construcción en las viviendas urbanas y rurales de la Provincia. Con esfuerzo y mucha incertidumbre inició este negocio hace 3 años, con el sueño de un día poder brindar a su familia una vida de calidad y excelencia. Su trabajo se alterna entre diseño de alacenas para cocinas, instalación de baldosa, azulejo, duelas en los pisos, paredes, pintura, puertas, etc. Es muy importante para este trabajo identificar bien los gustos de los clientes y las preferencias que tienen para la decoración de sus hogares. Ángel dedica a este trabajo 8 horas cada día en las cuales puede permanecer en una sola vivienda o atender varias. En el transcurso del tiempo, este hombre sin duda luchador, ha visto la necesidad de incurrir en la compra de algunas herramientas que facilitarán y agilitarán su trabajo, para lo cual solicita un crédito que le ayudará en la compra de estas herramientas. El mayor obstáculo que Ángel ha tenido para fortalecer su negocio es la falta de capital por la dificultad de las instituciones financieras para otorgar créditos a las personas de escasos recursos de las zonas rurales. Sin embargo, gracias a la recomendación de un ejecutivo de crédito de Fundación Alternativa, ha encontrado el apoyo y asesoría que él esperaba. Ángel da gracias a las personas alrededor del mundo que a través de Kiva aportan para que él obtenga el capital que desde hace tanto tiempo le ha hecho falta.
texts.en:
Ángel is 25 years old and only was able to finish high school through much effort.  He is single and, thanks to the entreprenurial spirit he inherited, has been able to provide for his family.  He lives with his partner and son in the parish of Río Verde de Santo Domingo which is the capital of the province of Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas in Ecuador.  This province has shown considerable sustained growth over the last few years.  The capital is known for its delicious fruit and gastronomy, and has become the major commercial route between the sierra and coastal regions of the country.  Both local and foreign tourists visit the many tourist attractions and warm climate.  Most of the inhabitants are involved in some type of commercial or service business catering to the local population and tourists.

Ángel learned his trade from his father.  He is a construction worker in urban and rural residential areas of the province.  He started his business three years ago, with much effort and uncertainty, in an effort to give his family a better quality of life.  He alternates his work with designing kitchens, installing tile and flooring, painting walls, doors, etc.  This job requires being able to identify a customer's preferences for home decoration.  Ángel works eight hours a day, either in a single house or among several.  Over time, this hard worker has observed a need to buy certain tools to help facilitate his work, so he is requesting a loan to buy these tools.  Ángel's greatest obstacle for strengthening his business has been the lack of capital.  This is due to the fact that lending institutions are not likely to give loans to low-income earners in rural areas.  However, thanks to the recommendation of a loan executive at Fundación Alternativa, he has found the support and advice he hoped for.  Ángel is grateful to people around the world who, through Kiva, are giving him the capital he so badly needs.

loans.use: To buy construction work tools.

loans.name: Hayrapet

texts.ru:
Айрапету 28 лет . Он окончил Каджаранскую среднюю  школу , после  поступил и окончил Капанский коледж по специальности  работник связи . 
После колледжа  в 2010г. Айрапет поступил на 2-ой курс Гориского Государственного Университета на  заочный факультет электроэнергетики . 
Айрапет живет со своими  родителями в городе Капане. Родители  Айрапета пенсионеры. Уже почти как 5лет ,как он работает на  гидроэлектростанции .
Айрапет занимается также пчеловодством. Его семья имеет небольшой участок земли и собственный дом в селе Нор Астхаберд (Nor Astghaberd)  Сюникской области. 
Айрапету нужен кредит на сумму 170.000 Армянских драм для оплаты за учебу на 2013 год.
texts.en:
Hayrapet is 28 years old. He has graduated from the Kadjaran Secondary School, then entered the Kapan College and graduated as a communications specialist. After college, in 2010, Hayrapet enrolled as a second-year correspondence student in the faculty of Electrical Energy of the Gorisk State University.

Hayrapet lives with his retired parents. For almost 5 years, he has been working at a hydroelectric station. He is also engaged in bee keeping. Hayrapet's family has a small parcel of land and a house in the village of Nor Astghberd in the Syuniksk region.

Hayrapet needs a loan of 170,000 Armenian dram to pay his tuition in 2013.

loans.use: to pay his tuition fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bee hives and pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 28-year-old Fatmata from Torkpoi town, Bo. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 12 months and 9 years. She began her business because her husband is not working; she has to create income to support the home.

Fatmata runs a cookery business where she sells local food. She has been running this business for 5 years. She works at the business every day from morning to night. Her business is the only income she has. She says that her main challenge is insufficient capital to run her business.

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to buy food stuffs and bags of rice for her cookery business. The extra income from this loan will allow her to change her level of living and expand her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy food stuffs and bags of rice for her cookery business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bee hives and pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth sells provisions in Apowa near Takoradi. Elizabeth has received a secondary school education. She is divorced and has 6 children. Elizabeth has been selling provisions in Apowa for the past 2 years. She is responsible for supporting herself and paying her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to purchase a greater quantity and variety of provisions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her provisions shop.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity and variety of provisions to sell.

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Philomina is a seamstress in Apowa near Takoradi. Philomina has received schooling through to a junior high school level. She is single and has no children. Philomina has been a seamstress for 3 years. She is responsible for supporting herself and paying all her own expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more material and supplies for her seamstress shop. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her shop.

loans.use: to buy more material and supplies for her seamstress shop.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is married and has 4 children. She has received schooling through to middle school. Margaret sells kenkey in Apowa near Takoradi, which she has done for 10 years. Her husband is a petty trader in the community, who sells soft drinks. Margaret uses her income to support her husband with their family's expenses. Margaret will use the loan to purchase more corn to prepare her kenkey to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Margaret plans to expand her kenkey-making trade further.

loans.use: to purchase more corn to prepare her kenkey to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bee hives and pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Rakia

texts.en: Rakia is divorced and has 5 children. She has received no formal education. Rakia sells underwear in Apowa near Takoradi and has done so for 5 years now. Rakia uses her income to support her children and pay their school fees. Rakia will use the loan to buy a greater quantity and variety of men's and women's underwear for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Rakia plans to expand her underwear clothing trade.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and variety of men's and women's underwear for sale.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca sells footwear in Apowa near Takoradi. Rebecca has received schooling through to junior high school. She is single and has 3 children. Rebecca has been selling footwear for the past 2 years. She is responsible for paying her children’s school fees and covering her family’s expenses. Her loan will be used to buy a greater quantity and variety of footwear for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to increase her capital base and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and variety of footwear for sale.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina is a seamstress in Apowa near Takoradi. Ernestina has received schooling through junior high school.  She is single and has no children. 

Ernestina has been a seamstress for two years. She is responsible for supporting herself and paying all her own expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more material and supplies to make clothes. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to grow her seamstress shop.

loans.use: to buy more material and supplies to make clothes.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a seamstress in Apowa near Takoradi. Regina has received no formal education.  She is married and has no children. Her husband is a driver. 

Regina has been a seamstress for the past six years now. She is responsible for helping her husband with their family’s general expenses. Her loan will be used to buy more material and supplies for her seamstress shop. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her seamstress shop.

loans.use: to buy more materials and supplies for her seamstress shop.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary sells fish in Apowa near Takoradi. Mary has received schooling through primary level.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a miner. 

Mary has been selling fish for the past 20 years. She is responsible for helping to support her husband and children. Her loan will be used to buy a greater quantity of fish to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her fish-selling trade.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity of fish to sell.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is a fishmonger and sells smoked and fried fish in Apowa near Takoradi. Vida has received school through junior high school.  She is married and has four children.  Her husband is a driver. 

Vida has been a fishmonger selling fish for five years now. She is responsible for helping her husband with their family’s general expenses. Her loan will be used to buy a greater quantity of fish to prepare and sell in the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to grow her fish selling enterprise.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity of fish to prepare and sell in the market.

loans.name: Agartha

texts.en:
Agartha is a seamstress in Apowa near Takoradi. Agartha has received schooling through secondary school level.  She is married and has four children. 

Agartha has been working as a seamstress for the past 15 years. She is responsible for helping her husband with their family's expenses. Her loan will be used to purchase more materials and supplies for her seamstress shop. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her seamstress trade.

loans.use: to purchase more materials and supplies for her seamstress shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy retail stock, e.g., rice, sugar, flour, cooking oil, etc.

loans.name: Aniceta

texts.en:
Aniceta, a business lady living in Nanyuki, is glad about being in Milango. After her introduction to Milango, she purchased tea tree seedlings from the first loan she received.

Aniceta would like to expand the farm and is applying for an additional loan of 10,734 Kenya shillings to purchase more tea tree seedlings.

loans.use: to purchase tea tree seedlings for farming.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 58 years old, married and supports six children between the ages of 32 and 15 years.

Grace rears poultry at her farm and has been in operation for a period of one year, earning a monthly income of KES 20,000. She is servicing her second loan of KES 70,000 from KADET LTD after repaying the previous one successfully, and she intends to use this amount to purchase more chicks for rearing and sell later at a profit. 

She will use the anticipated profit to expand her poultry farming.

loans.use: To purchase  more chicks for rearing and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is a widow and has no children. She has received no formal education. Ama sells bread at Mpredwow, near Cape Coast, which she has done for 40 years now. Ama uses her income to pay for her personal expenses. 

Ama will use the loan to purchase more ingredients, such as flour, butter, and sugar, to bake bread for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to improve upon her bread-baking business.

Ama is standing by her oven.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients, such as flour, butter, and sugar, to bake bread for sale.

loans.name: Viola

texts.en:
Viola still hawks milk and has been in operation for a period of four years, earning a monthly income of KES 12,000.

Viola is paying her previous loan and now she has requested another loan which is her third loan of KES 50,000 from KADET LTD.  She wishes to use this loan to pay the milk suppliers. 

The profits she earns will be used to repay the loan and for her family's upkeep. Viola's dream is to prosper in her business and live happily.

loans.use: to pay the milk suppliers

loans.name: Yayah

texts.en:
Forty-four-year-old Yayah is married and has two children aged nineteen and sixteen. His dependent father also lives with him. 

In 2001, Yayah began selling garri (cassava flakes) because he needed to alleviate his domestic difficulties. His business is the only source of livelihood for him and his family. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, he earns about 7,600,000 SLL every month. The rising cost of transportation is his major challenge, though, and competition is extremely high.

Yayah would like a loan of 5,000,000 SLL in order to buy more garri to sell. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly income by approximately 751,000 SLL. 

In the future, Yayah plans to purchase and install a garri processing machine in his village and to give his children a quality education. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more garri to sell.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat is a resident of Mombasa, Kenya. He is married and has three school-going children. Josephat is a motor vehicle mechanic who has been in the business for twenty years. He currently works as a contracted mechanic. Josephat has also invested in the transport business. 

Josephat was invited to Milango by his friends and is applying for a loan of 62,650 Kenya shillings to carry out body work on his vehicle. His ambition is to be a motor vehicle dealer. He is hopeful that the revenue from this vehicle will increase his income which will form part of the savings for his project.

loans.use: To carry out body work on his vehicle.

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is 38 years old and supports a family of three. He is a small scale, mixed crop farmer. He farms as a source of income to meet his financial needs as well as for his family. He grows a variety of cereal grains and vegetables. He has been in business for the last seven years and makes a monthly income of 12,000 KES.

He borrowed a loan in the amount of 9,000 KES for a period of six months which he intends to use to purchase farming inputs for this year's planting season.

He anticipates earning a profit, and he plans to put the additional income back into the business. He also intends to save some money for his children's education.

loans.use: To purchase inputs for farming

loans.name: Martin

texts.en: Martin, a businessman living in Nanyuki, is happy to be a member of Milango. After his introduction to Milango and accessing the first loan, he purchased tea tree seedlings. He has heard about the potential of growth in the business and is willing to invest more. Martin would like to expand the farm and is applying for an additional loan of 14,850 Kenya shillings to purchase more tea tree seedlings.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for his business.

loans.name: Jeremy

texts.en: Jeremy, a businessman living in Nanyuki, is tea tree farmer. He purchased tea tree seedlings from the first loan he received. Jeremy has heard about the potential of growth in the business and is willing to invest more. He would like to expand the farm and is applying for an additional loan of 20,730 Kenya shillings to purchase more tea tree seedlings.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for his farm.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a businessman living in Nanyuki. He purchased tea tree seedlings from the first loan he received. He has heard about the potential of growth in the business and is willing to invest more. Julius would like to expand the farm and is applying for an additional loan of 10,734 Kenya shillings to purchase more tea tree seedlings.

loans.use: to buy tea tree seedlings for his farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy welding plates, rods, sets of spanners, and motor vehicle spare parts for his business.

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es: Marlene propietaria de una miscelánea, adquirió un credikiva para comprar una vitrina y efectivamente lo hizo, así mismo compró comestibles con la que la surtió, razón por la cual su negocio tenía una imagen diferente.  Hoy   está más surtido, pero tiene una mayor rotación y muchas veces los inventarios son insuficientes para atender su demanda. Esta es justamente la razón, por la cual sus compras también tienen una corta frecuencia, pero como todo lo vende se siente feliz. En la actualidad aprovechará a su cautiva clientela para ofrecerle helados, por eso comprará un congelador que surtirá con deliciosos helados elaborado con los  tropicales sabores naturales de frutas del caribe Colombiano, para que su clientela disfrute de las brisas y el sol costero, bien refrescados consumiendo este producto. Esta es la razón por la cual acude nuevamente a un credikiva y lo hará que sea muy exitoso porque está en plena época de carnaval, donde todo lo que refresque se vende.
texts.en: Marlene, who owns a convenience store, obtained a Kiva loan to buy a display cabinet.  She did, indeed, buy one and, at the same time, she purchased foodstuffs to stock it.   In the process, she gave her shop a completely new image.  It is now better stocked, but has a faster turnover and her buffer stock is often insufficient to meet demand. This means that her purchases do not last long, but she feels happy because she sells everything.  She will now capitalise on her captive clientele to offer them ice creams and will buy a freezer which she will stock with delicious ice creams made with the natural tropical flavours of fruits from Colombia's Caribbean coast.  As her customers eat the product, they will be refreshed by the breezes and coastal sunshine.  She is, therefore, applying for another Kiva loan and her plan should be very successful because it is the height of the Carnival season, when everything refreshing sells well.

loans.use: to buy a freezer which she will stock with delicious ice creams

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es: Andrea en su negocio de venta de cervezas invirtió todo su credikiva; ella compró muchas canastas con las que abasteció su oferta y aumentó su capital de trabajo. En la actualidad está preparándose para los carnavales, época en la cual el incremento de sus ventas es muy usual. Como conoce el negocio sabe que debe tener mucho inventario, no solo para vender directamente a su clientela, sino también para distribuir en las tiendas de licores, cuando estas se terminen. Esta es justamente la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, pues una vez mas, se esforzará trabajando fuertemente, para lograr prosperar cada día con más énfasis. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente: “Muchas gracias por esos aportes y ayudas que han beneficiado a su negocio pero en especial a su familia”. Su nuevo crédito al que hoy aplica, lo invertirá en la compra de cervezas y en  carpas, para que sus clientes estén mas cómodos y disfruten sus fiestas familiares en su negocio disfrazados y bailando al son de los tambores..
texts.en: Andrea has a business selling beer. She invested her whole Kiva loan, buying lots of cases and increasing her stock and working capital. Right now she is getting ready for carnival, when sales normally increase. She knows the business and knows she should have a lot more inventory, not just to sell directly to her customers, but to distribute to liquor stores when they run out. That is the reason that she has turned to a Kiva loan. Once again, she will work very hard to be able to really prosper more every day. Her message to the Kiva lenders is the following: "Thank you very much for your contributions and help that have benefitted my business and especially my family."  The new loan she is applying for today will be invested in buying beer and in tents, so her customers are more comfortable and can enjoy family gatherings at her business, masked and dancing to the beat of the drums.

loans.use: to buy beer and tents,

loans.name: Vitoria

texts.en: Vitoria is applying for a 1000 dollar loan to improve her restaurant. She has a restaurant near by the main road and her restaurant is in a very strategic location where many customers frequently come to eat. She will use the loan to buy some additional supplies to keep in her restaurant such as rice, meat, other ingredients, soft drinks and hard drinks to serve the customers who come to her restaurant.

loans.use: to buy rice, meat, other ingredients, soft drinks and hard drinks

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
This is Melanie, 35, resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Jonathan and mother to their children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Melanie operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those round palm-sized ones, to the much larger doormats and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. 

Melanie dreams of having their own house and hopes to give her children a good life and a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fabric, cloth, thread and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is from Bagumbang, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old and married with two children. To make a living, Winnie manages a liquor store business. Winnie has been engaged in her business for 12 years and earns 15,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2011, Winnie joined GDMPC. Winnie is requesting a loan of 28,0000 PHP, to obtain more liquor items to sell. She aims to expand her business one day.

loans.use: to obtain more liquor items to sell.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
This is Lilia. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to buy spare parts, accessories and for the maintenance of her van unit. Her earnings were a big help for her children's education, in their personal, household and business expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

She would like to apply for another loan of 22,000 PHP to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their van unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and children's education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Lilia dreams of giving her family a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of their van.

loans.name: Edmun

texts.en:
This is Edmun. His previous loan was a big help in his business. He was able to buy the needed spare parts for his tricycle and the loan also helped in the education of his children. He and his wife are working hard to provide income for their family. He is also into rice retailing for additional income.

He would like to apply for another 8,000 PHP loan for him to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of their tricycle unit. His profits from his business will definitely help him to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart. 

Edmun hopes to see his businesses growing and dreams of a good life for his family. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and the maintenance of his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
Myra is 32 years old, married and has three children. Two are attending elementary school. To supplement her spouse's income which is derived from selling hogs, she sells "ukay-ukay" (used clothing) and earns about 15,000 PHP in income monthly. Aside from selling clothes she also buys and sells longganisa (cured pork) to get additional income. She keeps on diversifying her business to gain more profits. 

Myra joined ASKI and is now asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy more used clothing, shoes and bags to sell. This will help increase sales capacity and profits as well. 

Some day, Myra hopes to keep offering good products and services to ensure loyalty from her customers. She will save her revenue to use for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy more used clothing, shoes and bags to sell.

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette lives in Tuguegarao. She is single and generates income from her stall where she sells office supplies and computer parts. She has been in her business for over a year now and approximately earns PHP 25,000 each month. She uses her income as revolving capital in the business. Other parts were saved for future expenses. 

She aims to keep making her business profitable which is why she asked for a loan of PHP 50,000 to buy more computer parts, ink refills, colored papers and pens to sell on her stall. She hopes to keep extending her good services and the quality of products to all her customers. With the good products she offers, she will enhance her sales and keep her business profitable. 

Some day, she hopes to became a successful entrepreneur and achieve financial stability.

loans.use: to buy more computer parts, ink refills, colored papers and pens to sell on her stall.

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi is very happy about her association with Milango Financial Services. The previous loan helped increase the farm's harvest. She is ready to improve upon last year's work.

Sidi is applying for a loan of KES 10,650 (Kenya shillings) to prepare the farm and buy seeds and fertilizer. She intends to save the additional income for future projects and her main ambition is to improve upon her fruit farm. She is a member of a lending group through which she received the loan. It has a name called “adui ni njaa”; translated as 'hunger is the enemy'. All other members in the group are farmers and are working hard towards food security.

loans.use: to cultivate her land and buy seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Everlides Isabel

texts.es: Everlides con su credikiva compró una nevera, carne de res, pescado, tubérculos y verduras con los que surtió y dio una nueva imagen al negocio. Sus  ganancias se vieron aumentadas ligeramente y está muy contenta, porque ofreció una forma de pago más cómoda a sus clientes. Su negocio hoy, está mas estable, pues el  credikiva lo fortaleció y ella muy motivada trabaja mucho para sostenerlo, y sacar adelante a su familia. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente: “Muy agradecida por la ayuda brindada, espero seguir contando con su apoyo”. Su credikiva tendrá éxito porque con el logrará, adecuar su negocio con nuevos utensilios de cocina, mesas, sillas y víveres en mayor volumen,  para preparar sus alimentos con mas comodidad y a un mejor precio.
texts.en: Everlides bought a refrigerator, beef, fish, tubers and vegetables with her Kiva loan to stock her business and give it a new image. Her earnings increased slightly and she is happy because she was able to offer more comfortable payment terms to her customers. Today her business is more stable because the Kiva loan strengthened it and she is very motivated to work to support it and get her family ahead. Her message to the Kiva lenders is the following: " I am very grateful for the help that has been given. I hope to keep having your support". Her Kiva loan will be successful because with it she will be able to outfit her business with new kitchen utensils, tables, chairs and larger quantities of produce to prepare her food more easily and at a better price.

loans.use: to outfit her business with new cooking utensils, tables, chairs, and produce in a larger quantity.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
This is Helen. she previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy more gold and silver products for her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to cover their daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Helen hopes to have more branches for her business and dreams to have a good life with her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for gold and silver products needed in her business.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is from Riverside, Bonifacio. She is 32 years old. Delia is married and has two children. To make a living, she manages a fishpond where she raises fish, crabs and shrimp for sale. She has been engaged in her business for 14 years and earns 15,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2011, Delia joined GDMPC. Delia is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to buy young fish to raise and twine to expand the seafood-raising business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy young fish to raise and twine to expand the business

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
This is Norma. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She was able to buy all the needed products for her business and the loan also helped in the education of her children. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their family. She also has an electronic loading station for additional income.

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan to buy additional stock of coffee and herbal products for her business. She will also use the loan in buying electronic load. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to cover their daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Norma hopes that her business will grow bigger and dreams of having a simple, happy and a debt-free life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of coffee and herbal products needed in her business

loans.name: Dezelyn

texts.en:
This is Dezelyn. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, household and business expenditures. She has been in this business for eight years now and it is continuously growing. She also sells meat and rice. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their family.

She would like to apply for a 50,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help cover her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Dezelyn hopes that her variety store will become a grocery store and dreams of giving a quality education to her children. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina is 40 years and she is married. She has a kiosk to generate income for her family. She has been thinking how to run a big business but she does not have enough working capital. She feels better now that she has applied for her first loan of $1,000. She will buy some additional supplies to keep in her store such as soft drinks, hard drinks, body cremes and biscuits. She is happy with TRM (Tuba Rai Metin) that offers loans to poor people.

loans.use: to buy Coca-Cola, Sprite, cigarettes, and sugar.

loans.name: Mira

texts.en:
This is Mira. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She was able to buy all the needed grocery items and the loan was also a big help for her children's education expenses. She also has a piggery and a 'jeepney' for additional income. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their family.

She would like to apply for a 25,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help cover her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mira dreams of having a good life and a happy family. She hopes that her variety store will become a grocery store. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
This is Luzviminda, a 48-year-old married mother. Her previous loan was a big help to her business as she was able to buy all the products she needed for the expansion of her grocery store. The loan was also a big help in the education of her children. 

Thus, Luzviminda would like to apply for another loan of 12,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) so that she can buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better since more items to sell will result in better profits. Her increased income will help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Luzviminda dreams of having a good life with her family and hopes that her business will continue to grow. She faithfully meets up with her fellowship* co-members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages for her business.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 48 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries like sardines, bread, soft-drinks and beverages.

She has borrowed and repaid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from raising pigs and a tricycle transportation business. Emily aspires to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries like sardines, bread, soft-drinks and beverages.

loans.name: Nonato

texts.en:
This is Nonato, 53, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Nenita, a rug maker, and is a father to his children. He, together with his wife, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nonato maintains a tricycle business. He owns and drives one tricycle unit (motor cycle with sidecar) that carries up to four passengers to their destination within the community. He works from early in the morning until late in the evening. There are times when he drives in the late evening until the wee hours in order to have a bigger profit. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of Php300 in his transportation business every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a loan amount of Php17,000. He will be utilizing the loan to buy motorcycle parts for the maintenance of his tricycle unit. He has to maintain his unit in good condition in order to have a regular income for the daily needs of his family. 

Nonato hopes to have more customers for his tricycle and for his wife’s business. He simply dreams to have a happy family. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts for the maintenance of the tricycle unit.

loans.name: Byambasuren

texts.en:
Mrs. Byambasuren is 43 years old and lives with her family in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. She has been working as a seamstress in a leather factory for twenty four years. During her free time, she also makes dresses to order for local customers. Her parents reside in their own house on a plot of land while she rents an apartment in the city center. Her older daughter is studying at medical college in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

The house that Byambasuren's parents live in has deteriorated over the years and needs some repairs. So she is requesting a loan of 6,500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) to purchase construction materials such as paints, gypsum, planks and bricks. During this time of year, the price of construction materials generally reaches its lowest level.
